RelationshipElement.name: Bonded To
RelationshipElement.description: Implements a bonded to for contexts

RelationshipElement.name: Arbitrarily separated from
RelationshipElement.description: When two or more context codes have been assigned to what is ultimately determined to be the same context

RelationshipElement.name: Broadly contemporary with
RelationshipElement.description: Contexts suspected to be contemporary but no direct physical relationship or evidence (i.e. adjacent buildings)

RelationshipElement.name: EarlierLater
RelationshipElement.description: Implements a Stratigraphically Immediately Earlier-Later for contexts.

RelationshipElement.name: ContextMatrix
RelationshipElement.description: Implements a 1:N between contexts and matrices

RelationshipElement.name: ContextContextGroup
RelationshipElement.description: Implements a N:N between contexts and context groups

RelationshipElement.name: ContextArtefactGroup
RelationshipElement.description: Implements a 1:N between context and its artefact groups

RelationshipElement.name: ContextSample
RelationshipElement.description: Implements a 1:N between context and its samples

RelationshipElement.name: ContextSpecialFind
RelationshipElement.description: Implements a 1:N between context and its Small Finds

RelationshipElement.name: ContextPhotographLog
RelationshipElement.description: Implements a 1:N between context and its photograph logs

RelationshipElement.name: ContextHeight
RelationshipElement.description: Implements a 1:N between context and its heights

RelationshipElement.name: ContextGroupPhotographLog
RelationshipElement.description: Implements a 1:N between context group and its photograph logs

Context.desc: The physical result of any single action whether it leaves a positive or negative record within the stratigraphic sequence. (MoLAS 1994)

AreaCode.desc: The excavation trench, designated by a letter code and assigned automatically by the module based on your selection when you log in.

Context_ID.desc:
Every archaeological context (negative element (cut), deposit, structure, skeleton, artefact cluster) is given a unique 3 or 4 letter context code. Each trench is designated with a separate letter which starts the code, so it is immediately obvious to which trench a context belongs. For example context HAA belongs to Trench H, context MQP to Trench M etc.
The contexts are labelled consecutively in alphabetical order using the letters following the trench letter. For Trench H the first context would be HAA, the second HAB, the third HAB and so on. In addition sets of letters can denote parts of trenches, buildings etc. E.g. HFs might denote contexts from a specific building.
Burial context codes begin with the letter Z, followed by the trench letter. Hence burial ZHA is the first burial context from trench H.
Check with the trench supervisor who will assign the context code from the central register.

Context_Name.desc: Enter a brief, clear name for the Context eg 'House A - west wall'

Site_Code.desc: Short code to signify the excavation site and often the year of excavation. Assigned automatically by the module.

Excavators.desc: Initials of the excavators that have worked on the context.

Plans.desc: Reference numbers to plans or drawings of this Context.

Grid_X.desc: The X coordinate on the SW corner of the context.

Grid_Y.desc: The Y coordinate on the SW corner of the context.

Context_Type.desc: Describe the context type by selecting an icon as defined below. When you have selected a context type you can proceed to open the "Fill in context type details" page. Note this page will not open unless you have selected a context type.

opts.opt: {Cut} Any Context which represents the removal of earlier deposit and thus forms a negative interface (cut) with another context, such as a cut for a pit, burial, ditch, wall foundation or robber trench.
{Deposit} Any Context with deposited sediment and soil, such as floor layers, pit and grave fills, hearth fills and natural sediments.
{Structure} Any Context consisting of deliberately constructed structural element, independent of a Negative Element (i.e. cut, such as a wall or a hearth).

Date_Opened.desc: Date on which the Context was first excavated. This will automatically be set to the date on which the context is recorded but can be edited using the keyboard.

Date_Closed.desc: The date excavation of the Context ended and it was closed. Press the 'Add Date Closed' button to insert today's date.

Location_Note.desc: Record the approximate location in the excavation area, for example: centre of Area A; NW corner area A. Also include, where relevant, the position in relation to other archaeological contexts or features e.g. between walls x and y.

Excavation_Method.desc: Enter details here about the method of archaeological excavation.

opts.opt: {Other} Excavated by another method. Add details in Annotation field.

Highest_Level.desc: The highest elevation or 'starting level' recorded for that context relative to the site grid.

Lowest_Level.desc: The lowest elevation recorded for that context relative to the site grid.

Section_Numbers.desc: Reference numbers to section drawings of this Context

Soil_Compaction_Type.desc: Describe the compaction of the sediments in the Context.

opts.opt: {Friable} Deposit disintegrates into small particles under pressure.
{Crumbly} Deposit disintegrates into lumps under pressure.

Soil_Compaction_Description.desc: Description of the compaction of soil including changes throughout the deposit. Eg "Varies from loose to compact."

Soil_Texture_Helper.desc: This helper is based on the standard flow chart for determining soil texture. Start by taking 25g of soil and placing it in your palm. Select each option and follow the prompts for TASKS (like roll ribbon) until you get a result, eg 'silty loam'. Then click the 'Update' button to have that value pasted onto your Context record.

Soil_Texture.desc: The type of sediment, eg clay, silt, sand and loam. Use the {Texture_Helper} or a Soil Sediment diagram for assisance.

opts.opt: {No_Observation} No Observation. Use the Texture helper to prefil this.
{Sand} A sand has a loose gritty feel and does not stick together. Individual sand grains can be seen or felt. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
{Loamy_Sand} In a loamy sand particles barely stick together and a moulded piece of soil just holds its shape. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
{Silty_Clay_Loam} A silty clay loam is like a clay loam but silty as well and smooth to the touch. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

{Clay_Loam} More easily moulded into a shape than a loam a clay loam rolls out to a thin ribbon between the palms while a loam will break-up. When dry a clay loam will form a lump but is not as tough to break as a clay.(VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
{Sandy_Clay_Loam} A sandy clay loam is like a clay loam but sand grains can be felt (and heard - see Sandy Loam) (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

{Silt_Loam} A silty loam is like a loam but has a smooth silky feel when a moist sample is pushed between the index finger and thumb. On drying a sample can form a hard lump but this may be broken by hand. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

{Loam} A loam breaks into crumbs but will tend to stick together. Sand grains cannot be felt in a moist sample which when squeezed will retain its shape when handled freely. Loams are usually soft to the feel. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

{Sandy_Loam} A sandy loam sticks together more than a loamy sand but can be easily broken. Individual sand grains can be felt and heard if a wet sample is rubbed between the index finger and thumb and held close to the ear. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
{Silty_Clay} A silty clay is like a clay but smoother. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

{Clay} Clays are tough and can be moulded into shapes when moist. Clays form a long flexible ribbon when rubbed between the palms and the ribbon can often be bent into a U shape without breaking. Clays dry into very hard clods. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
{Sandy_Clay} A sandy clay is like a clay but sand grains can be felt (and heard - see Sandy Loam). (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

Soil_Particle_Sorting.desc: Assessment of the frequency with which particles of the same size occur.

opts.opt: {Moderately_sorted} Particles are mostly the same size and evenly distributed but there are some larger particles.
{Poorly_sorted} Particles are different sizes and unevenly distributed.
{Very_poorly_sorted} Particles are very different sizes and very unevenly distributed.
{Well_sorted} Particles are roughly the same size and evenly distributed.

Soil_Colour.desc: Broad colour description of the soil, eg 'mid greyish brown'.

Sterile.desc: Whether or not the deposit is sterile, ie contains no artefacts

Deposit_Inclusions.desc: Enter a brief description of inclusions (eg stone flecks artefacts).

Volume.desc: Estimate the volume of the context in litres. All soil will be collected in buckets of a known volume. A tally should be kept of buckets produced from a context and the total volume calculated using that tally.

Contamination.desc: The extent to which the context has been contaminated.

opts.opt: {Contaminated} Contaminated by later material eg by unidentified cut at time of initial excavation by large scale animal or root activity which were not isolated by excavation by excavation processes some annoying person mixed the material or stuff fell into deposit from the section.

{High_Likely_Contaminated} It is very likely that significant amounts of earlier artifact and ecofact material has become incorporated in the deposit. For example; is this context a mud brick wall or other structure or building or structural debris or a deposit which has seen the redeposition of material excavated from cuts. These are all situations in which earlier material is likely to have been dug up and re-used (in the mud brick) or re-deposited (when digging out pits).
{Low_Likely_Contaminated} You think there is little chance that very much earlier material has made it's way into this deposit.

{Primary_Deposit} You are very sure that the deposit and all finds therein directly relate to activity within a specific period of time and there is thus minimal amounts of derived material and no contamination.

Horizon_Boundary.desc: Describe the boundary between this and the next context.

opts.opt: {Doubtful}You are uncertain of whether you accurately excavated a boundary between deposits.
{Ambiguous}You are uncertain as to whether there was a boundary between contexts.
{Merging}There is a distinction between the excavated context and earlier context(s) but the excavated contexts and the earlier contexts grade into each other.
{Clear}The boundary with the earlier context(s) was very clearly defined during excavation.
{Arbitrary_Spit}There is no meaningful boundary with an earlier context. The boundary has been artificially created by the excavation process.

Shape_of_Cut.desc: Describe the shape of the negative element/cut viewed from above.

opts.opt: {Linear} Straight sided but not square or rectangular.
{Rectangular} Two sides longer than the other.

Shape_of_Cut_-.desc: Additional notes about the shape of the cut.

Shape_of_Corners.desc: Describe the shape of any visible corners of the negative element/cut.

Break_of_Slope_-.desc: The degree with which the top surface of the edge of the cut breaks into the sides.

opts.opt: {Not_perceptible} Well-rounded; there is no perceptible difference between the sides of the cut and the surface into which it protrudes.

Sides_of_Cut.desc: Describe the shape of the cut as seen in cross section.

Shape_of_Base.desc: The shape of the base of the cut in profile.

Cut_Function.desc: Comment in more specific detail on your understanding of the reasons for the shape and nature of the cut.

Orientation.desc: Orientation of linear cuts eg N-S.

Inclination_of_axis.desc: Inclination of the axis of post- and stakeholes.

Structure_Your_Interpretation.desc: Your interpretation of the likely function of the structure.

opts.opt: {Other} Function not elsewhere described. Provide details in Annotation field.

Cut_Your_Interpretation.desc: Your interpretation of the likely function of the Context using standardised definitions.

opts.opt: {Other} Function not elsewhere described. Provide details in Annotation field.

Deposit_Your_Interpretation.desc: Your interpretation of the likely function of the context.

opts.opt: {Indeterminate} You are unable to make an assessment of possible function.
{Packing} Packing in a post hole for post material fulfilling a constructional purpose other than deliberate levelling deposits.
{Levelling_Fill} Material laid down to level or raise an area for constructional purposes or other activities.
{Dump} Material probably dumped as a result of other activity e.g. material removed from cuts or other constructional or destructional activity.
{Midden} Distinct area of organic rubbish accumulation
{Burial} A fill or other deposit associated with a skeleton and forming part of a burial feature.
{Structural_Debris} Material derived from collapse of a wall, roof or other structure
{Partly_naturally_derived} A deposit partly or wholly accumulating through natural sedimentary processes, such as water or wind deposition.

{Wholly_naturally_derived} All of the deposit accumulating through the deposition of natural sediments through geomorphological processes eg wind borne sediments water-laid natural sediments material flaking from cave and rock shelter walls.
{Erosional_products} Material deriving from the erosion of earlier archaeological sediments.
{Artifact_cluster} A distinct concentration of artifacts or ecofacts. Make sure you record its xyz coordinates centre and edges.
{Ash_or_Charcoal} A deposit consisting largely of carbonized/charred plant material and/or ash

{Arbitrary} This applies to artificial contexts excavated for excavational convenience eg section cleaning material whose precise provenience is unclear. Does not include arbitrary spits or spatial units deliberately excavated for finer control of horizontal and vert

{Distinct_floor_contact} To be used for material that directly reflects the use of a surface or floor - artefact material on the surface perhaps thin deposits of occupation material. These contexts will be gridded into spatial units for closer control of artifact distributions.
{Animal_or_Plant} Deposit derived from plant or animal activity
{Other} Function not elsewhere described. Provide details in Annotation field.

Your_Discussion.desc: Enter an interpretation of the function of the Context and its place in the stratigraphical sequence.

Your_description.desc: Enter a verbal description of the Context, including its form, contexts, relationship to other Contexts and any other relevant information. This is the main place to record all other descriptive information that may be treated briefly or not covered elsewhere, including signs of disturbance by burrowing animals etc.

Sketch.desc: Upload the file of a sketch of the context drawn on another application using the button below

Photo.desc: Use this button to take a photo of the context using the camera on the tablet. Use a scale in the photo

Audio.desc: Use this button to record an audio file of your observations concerning this context

Video.desc: Use this button to record a video using the tablet of this context

Structural_Components.desc: Describe what the structure is made from.

opts.opt: {Stone} Worked or unworked stone used in masonry walls.
{Other} Material not otherwise described. Add description and notes in Annotation field.

Bonding.desc: Additional details of the bonding/packing material.

opts.opt: {Unmortared} No visible bonding material ie unmortared.

Bonding_Details.desc: What has been used to bind the major elements together? Is there mud mortar in a wall, or chinking stones?

Bond_Type.desc: The type of bonding course eg 'English bond'

Distinguishing_Marks.desc: Describe and distinguishing marks on the bricks or stone, such as makers marks, score marks etc.

Number_Courses.desc: The number of vertical layers of structural elements such as bricks.

Set_In_Cut.desc: Give the cut context code if relevant. If not set in cut then put 'NA'.

Structure_Shape.desc: The shape of the structural element, in plan.

opts.opt: {Linear} Straight sided but not square or rectangular.
{Rectangular} Two sides longer than the other.
{Rectangular} With straight edges, upper and lower surfaces.

Component_Finish.desc: How have the material types been prepared (i.e dressed stones polished/smoothed/painted plaster surface).

Composition_Type.desc: Describe the structure of the Context sediment. The components making up the structure are added below as aggregates.

opts.opt: {Heterogeneous} Deposit with different mixed components which need to be described.
{Laminated} Laminated Deposit consists of lots of fine lenses of the same material. Compact laminated Deposit consists of a number of fine lenses of different materials.
{Compact_Laminated} Deposit consists of a number of fine lenses of different materials

Deposit_Bedding.desc: Describes the base of the deposit

opts.opt: {Uneven} Mix of horizontal, oblique and undulating - make sure you describe this

Space.desc: Enter the space number, which may define an internal or external area in which the skeleton is located.

Building.desc: A building can comprise one or more internal spaces so enter the building number in which the skeleton is located.

Mid_X.desc: An appropriate mid-point on the skeleton under excavation should be recorded on the X / Y co-ordinates. This will locate the skeleton on the site grid system.

Mid_Y.desc: An appropriate mid-point on the skeleton under excavation should be recorded on the X / Y co-ordinates. This will locate the skeleton on the site grid system.

Skeleton_Dimensions.desc: Record the approximate extent of the skeletal remains (in meters or millimetres only) and the axis of measurement. Detailed dimensions can be taken from the plan.

Skeleton_Body.desc: Describe the attitude of the body, whether it is extended, crouched, flexed, supine (front up), prone (face down) and the orientation.

Skeleton_Head.desc: Which way up the head faces and/or points

Skeleton_Right_Arm.desc: Record whether right arm is straight or flexed, is along the side of the body, over the chest or on the pelvis, and the position of the hand.

Skeleton_Left_Arm.desc: Record whether left arm is straight or flexed, is along the side of the body, over the chest or on the pelvis, and the position of the hand.

Skeleton_Right_Leg.desc: Record whether the leg is straight or bent, crossed left over right or right over left and the position of the foot

Skeleton_Left_Leg.desc: Record whether the leg is straight or bent, crossed left over right or right over left and the position of the foot

Skeleton_Condition.desc: Describe the general condition of the skeleton and any comments on articulation. Any degeneration of bone in situ is important to record as well as accidental damage during excavation and lifting. Record disturbances through later activity or animal/root activity as well as damage due to stone pressure on the bones. It is important to note whether the patellae, hyoid, phalanges, basi-occipital etc are present or not, and their location, as this may give an indication of the state of the body at the time of interment.

Skeleton_Surface_Modifications.desc: Note any cut marks, evidence of stains and/or colour during the course of the excavation, burning, chewing marks, root activity etc.

Skeleton_Environment.desc: The physical environment at the time of excavation may affect the state of the bone therefore it is important to note the weather and conditions you are working in.

Skeleton_Days_Exposed.desc: It is important to excavate skeletal remains as quickly as possible as the state of the bone will change during exposure. Any conditional change should also be noted. Excavate as quickly as possible because the bones will degrade rapidly.

Target_A_X.desc: The X coordinate of Target A. Targets are white-painted, large-headed nails used to rectify photographs.

Target_A_Y.desc: The Y coordinate of Target A. Targets are white-painted, large-headed nails used to rectify photographs.

Target_A_Z.desc: The Z coordinate of Target A. Targets are white-painted, large-headed nails used to rectify photographs.

Target_B_X.desc: The X coordinate of Target B. Targets are white-painted, large-headed nails used to rectify photographs.

Target_B_Y.desc: The Y coordinate of Target B. Targets are white-painted, large-headed nails used to rectify photographs.

Target_B_Z.desc: The Z coordinate of Target B. Targets are white-painted, large-headed nails used to rectify photographs.

Target_C_X.desc: The X coordinate of Target C. Targets are white-painted, large-headed nails used to rectify photographs.

Target_C_Y.desc: The Y coordinate of Target C. Targets are white-painted, large-headed nails used to rectify photographs.

Target_C_Z.desc: The Z coordinate of Target C. Targets are white-painted, large-headed nails used to rectify photographs.

Target_D_X.desc: The X coordinate of Target D. Targets are white-painted, large-headed nails used to rectify photographs.

Target_D_Y.desc: The Y coordinate of Target D. Targets are white-painted, large-headed nails used to rectify photographs.

Target_D_Z.desc: The Z coordinate of Target D. Targets are white-painted, large-headed nails used to rectify photographs.

SearchHelp.desc: This allows you to find any contexts that contain your search term or string in any field in a context record. Type in your term/string and press the "Search" button. Press "My Contexts" to return to the full list of contexts for this trench.

AreaCode.desc: The excavation trench, designated by a letter code and assigned automatically by the module based on your selection when you log in.

Context_Group_ID.desc: Feature number taken from the central register.

Title.desc: Enter the Feature name e.g. Hearth in Building 2.

Site_Code.desc: Short code to signify the excavation site and often the year of excavation. Assigned automatically by the module.

Location_Note_CG.desc: Record where the feature is within a space / building/area if relevant and in particular its relationship to other features or key contexts.

Building.desc: Identify the building in which the feature is located.

Space.desc: Identify the space in which the feature is located if relevant.

CG_Context_Type.desc: Enter the type of feature you are describing.

opts.opt: {Cut} Any Context which forms a negative interface (cut) with another context, such as a cut for a pit, burial, ditch, wall foundation or robber trench.
{Deposit} Any Context with deposited sediment and soil, such as floor layers, pit and grave fills, hearth fills and natural sediments.
{Structure} Any Context consisting of deliberately constructed structures, independent of a Negative Element (i.e. cut, such as walls and hearths).
{Wall} A structured vertical barrier made from durable materials defining a space.
{Floor} A prepared surface, internal or external, including those made from plaster, earth etc.
{Well} A deep pit excavated to reach the water table.
{Pit} A large cut filled with sediment or other materials.
{Room} A discrete space within a house or other building.
{Burial} The cut, fill plus any associated structures relating to the deposition of human remains, including those remains, such as a skeleton.
{Building} A building is defined when several walls surround a discrete space
{Surface} A compacted horizontal layer, internal or external, on which activities took place.
{Space} A space is an area bounded by a structure of some kind, either external or internal, and can be for example a courtyard, room, ante-room etc.
{Posthole}A small pit cut to hold an upright post.
{Stakehole}Cuts smaller than postholes, typically c. 1-5 cm diameter.
{Hearth}A prepared structure in which a fire is set.
{Stakehole_row} A row of cuts smaller than postholes, typically c. 1-5 cm diameter.
{Other}Function not elsewhere described. Provide details in Annotation field.

CG_Your_Interpretation.desc: Describe your understanding of the feature function, phasing etc.

CG_Your_description.desc: Describe the feature, any details of dimensions, disturbance, orientation etc.

Your_Discussion.desc: Add here any elaborations on the interpretation and description.

Mid_X.desc: An appropriate mid-point on the feature should be recorded on the X/Y coordinates. This will locate the feature on the site grid system.

Mid_Y.desc: An appropriate mid-point on the feature should be recorded on the X/Y coordinates. This will locate the feature on the site grid system.

CG_Phase_Notes.desc: The site or building phase in which this feature was constructed or deposited.

CG_Plans.desc: Reference numbers to plans or drawings of this feature.

CG_Section_Numbers.desc: Reference numbers to section drawings of this feature

Sketch.desc: Upload the file of a sketch of the feature drawn on another application using the button below

Photo.desc: Use this button to take a photo of the feature using the camera on the tablet. Remember to include a scale in the photo.

Audio.desc: Use this button to record an audio file of your observations concerning this feature

Video.desc: Use this button to record a video using the tablet of this feature

Percentage.desc: Enter the approximate % volume of this material in the Context.

Component.desc: Describe the components which make up 10% or more of the deposit.

opts.opt: {Midden} Organic debris e.g. bones carbonised material phytoliths etc
{Mudbrick} Fragments of mudbrick or whole mudbricks not part of a coherent structural element.
{Ash} White/grey fine material which may contain charcoal and other burnt plant material.
{Artefacts} Human manufactured materials including lithics, beads, ground stone etc.

AreaCode.desc: The excavation trench, designated by a letter code and assigned automatically by the module based on your selection when you log in.

Shape.desc: Shape and roundness of stones and pebbles in the deposit.

opts.opt: {Dressed_Stone} Those that have been clearly shaped for use.
{Tabular} Stones with flattened upper and lower surfaces.
{Ground} Stones that have been deliberately shaped smooth by grinding.

Number.desc: Add a short description of the point being recorded, for example, 1. North edge of floor, 2. South edge of floor. Mark your points on the sketch for each context.

X.desc: Add X coordinate using the site grid

Y.desc: Add Y coordinate using the site grid

Z.desc: Add Z coordinate using the site grid

Notes.desc: Add a description here concerning the entity whose position you have recorded

AreaCode.desc: The excavation trench, designated by a letter code and assigned automatically by the module based on your selection when you log in.

Sample.desc: Deposit samples or samples of building elements recovered from this Context for the purpose of further analysis or ongoing reference.

AreaCode.desc: The excavation trench, designated by a letter code and assigned automatically by the module based on your selection when you log in.

Context_ID.desc: Unique number or code for the Context from which this Artefact Cluster was collected.

Sample_ID.desc: The unique code or reference for the Sample. This should be assigned with reference to the central register

Sample_Type.desc: The type of Sample collected as detailed below.

opts.opt: {Building_Materials} Sample of bricks or worked stone collected from this Context.
{Soil} General collection of soil deposit from the Context.
{Wood/Charcoal} Collection of wood or charcoal fragments from the Context.
{C14_Sample}An organic sample recovered for radiocarbon dating.
{Flot_Sample}Flotation sample for recovery of plant remains.
{Phytolith_Sample} Small soil sample for phytolith analysis.
{Thin_Section} Specially collected blocks for soil thin sectioning.
{Animal_Bone} A sample of bone identified as animal.
{Human_Bone} A sample of bone identified as human.
{Other} Sample not elsewhere described. Include details in Annotation field.

Site_Code.desc: Short code to signify the excavation site and often the year of excavation. Assigned automatically by the module.

Sample_Volume.desc: Volume (in litres) of the sample collected.

Sample_Comments.desc: Additional comments about this sample or its collection.

Sample_Location.desc: The storage location of the sample at the time of entry.

Sample_X.desc: The reading from the x-axis (horizontal) of an arbitrary site grid corresponding to the location of the Sample at the time of excavation.

Sample_Y.desc: The reading from the y-axis (vertical) of an arbitrary site grid corresponding to the location of the Sample at the time of excavation.

Sample_Z.desc: The elevation or depth of the Sample at the time of excavation.

Structural_Components.desc: Primary components of structure or feature eg dry-pressed brick rough-hewn stone.

Bonding.desc: Primary bonding material of structure or feature eg mortar.

opts.opt: {Unmortared} No visible bonding material ie unmortared

Distinguishing_Marks.desc: stinguishing marks on brick or stone.

Structure_Description.desc: Other description about structural elements eg slate dry-proofing.

Sketch.desc: Upload the file of a sketch of the sample/sample location drawn on another application using the button below

Photo.desc: Use this button to take a photo of the sample/sample location using the camera on the tablet

Audio.desc: Use this button to record an audio file of your observations concerning this sample

Video.desc: Use this button to record a video using the tablet of this sample

AreaCode.desc: The excavation trench, designated by a letter code and assigned automatically by the module based on your selection when you log in.

Context_ID.desc: Unique number or code for each Context.

Special_Find_ID.desc: Unique number or code for the artefact applying either a Small Find or Groundstone number from the site register.

Special_Find_Class.desc: Broad Artefact Class for each Artefact (eg Chipped stone, Clay object, Building Material).

opts.opt: {Miscellaneous} Add detail in the Annotation field

Source.desc: Record the source of the artefact and whether it was collected during the excavation at the trench or from a sample

Special_Find_Location.desc: The storage location of the artefact at the time of entry.

Site_Code.desc: Short code to signify the excavation site and often the year of excavation. Assigned automatically by the module.

Special_Find_Name.desc: Enter a brief name for or description of the artefact e.g. Ground Stone Pounder

Special_Find_X.desc: The reading from the x-axis (horizontal) of an arbitrary site grid corresponding to the location of the Small Find at the time of excavation.

Special_Find_Y.desc: The reading from the y-axis (vertical) of an arbitrary site grid corresponding to the location of the Small Find at the time of excavation.

Special_Find_Z.desc: The elevation or depth of the Small Find at the time of excavation.

Special_Find_Comment.desc: Enter any additional observations concerning the artefact, its context and/or events surrounding it, for example damage or breakage suring excavation and storage.

Photo.desc: Use this button to take a photo of the artefact etc using the camera on the tablet. Make sure the artefact is shown with a scale

Audio.desc: Use this button to record an audio file of your observations concerning this artefact

Video.desc: Use this button to record a video using the tablet of this artefact etc

Photograph_Log.desc: A record of images created and stored on another device, eg by a professional site photographer.

AreaCode.desc: The excavation trench, designated by a letter code and assigned automatically by the module based on your selection when you log in.

Photo_Context_ID.desc: Unique number or code for each Context

Photo_Context_Group_ID.desc: Unique number or code for each Context Group

Photograph_Reference_ID.desc: Unique number or code allocated by creator of the image. It could be a filename or a reference number

Site_Code.desc: Short code to signify the excavation site and often the year of excavation.

Scene_Type.desc: The type of scene captured, eg opening or closing view of the Context. (Vocab: Open, Close, Other)

opts.opt: Open Photograph taken on opening the Context.
Close Photograph taken on closing the Context.
Other Scene not elsewhere described. Enter detail into Annotation field.

AreaCode.desc: The excavation trench, designated by a letter code and assigned automatically by the module based on your selection when you log in.

Timestamp.desc: The date this entry is created will automatically appear here

CreatedName.desc: Your name will be added here based on your login

Title.desc: Give your entry a simple, short title, such as Daily Trench Update, Burial 34, Storm Damage. Note that diary entries allow you to add information in addition to the context, feature and artefact records elsewhere in the module and should not be the primary description point for those entities

Text.desc: Record your diary entry here in as much detail as necessary and append with photographs, video and/or audio

Audio.desc: Use this button to record an audio file of your observations concerning this entry

Video.desc: Use this button to record a video relevant to this entry using the tablet's camera
